revision.text: {{Talkheader}} {{ArticleHistory |action1=GAN |action1date=13:21, 26 May 2010 |action1link=Talk:SMS Schleswig-Holstein/GA1 |action1result=listed |action1oldid=364293308 |action2=GTC |action2date=02:15, 27 June 2010 (UTC) |action2link=Wikipedia:Featured topic candidates/Deutschland class battleships/archive1 |action2result=promoted |action2oldid=369615017 |action3=GTC |action3date=02:55, 25 August 2011 |action3link=Wikipedia:Featured topic candidates/Battleships of Germany/archive1 |action3result=promoted |action4=WAR |action4date=00:43, 9 March 2013 |action4link=Wikipedia:WikiProject Military history/Assessment/SMS Schleswig-Holstein |action4result=approved |action4oldid=542139288 |ftname=Battleships of Germany |topic=War |action5=FAC |action5date=10:01, 14 December 2013 |action5link=Wikipedia:Featured article candidates/SMS Schleswig-Holstein/archive1 |action5result=promoted |action5oldid=586026041 |currentstatus=FA }} {{WikiProjectBannerShell|1= {{WikiProject Ships|class=FA}} {{MILHIST|class=FA|A-Class=pass|Maritime=yes|German=yes|WWI=yes|WWII=yes|OMT=1}} {{WikiProject Germany|class =FA|importance = low}} {{ShipwrecksWikiProject|class =FA|importance = }} }} == Article name == Why is this article not just titled [[Schleswig-Holstein]]? [[User:Remy B|Remy B]] 11:35, 28 September 2007 (UTC) :OK, now I see. Why not [[Schleswig-Holstein (battleship)]] or [[Schleswig-Holstein (German battleship)]] then? [[User:Remy B|Remy B]] 11:35, 28 September 2007 (UTC) ::It would be best titled [[SMS Schleswig-Holstein]], like her sisters [[SMS Pommern]] and [[SMS Hannover]] are. I suppose the argument for keeping the article as it's titled now is that the Schleswig-Holstein (as well as her sister Schlesien) also served in the Kriegsmarine, so they did not have the SMS prefix (DKM, contrary to popular opinion, was never used), so it isn't entirely correct to name the article SMS Schleswig-Holstein. [[User:Parsecboy|Parsecboy]] 16:25, 28 September 2007 (UTC) == WikiProject Military history/Assessment/Tag & Assess 2008 == Article reassessed and graded as start class. --[[User:Dashiellx|dashiellx]] ([[User talk:Dashiellx|talk]]) 14:37, 6 May 2008 (UTC) == Discrepancy concerning the ship's armament in 1939 == The account of the shelling of Westerplatte in September 1939 mentions 15cm guns. However, the table of armament in 1939 does not mention this caliber. I suppose the table is inexact. The corresponding Wikipedia page in German says the ship had fourteen 15cm guns in 1939. The Polish version mentions twelve such guns. —Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[Special:Contributions/188.33.223.33|188.33.223.33]] ([[User talk:188.33.223.33|talk]]) 02:33, 13 February 2010 (UTC) ==Soviet use== I was surprised to read that the Soviet Navy commissioned ''Schleswig-Holstein'' as a battleship — under her original name, no less. Can this be correct? I would have thought she was badly damaged by bombing and scuttling, and would have been raised only for scrap. It just seems unlikely, particularly since she was by then old and obsolete. [[User:Sca|Sca]] ([[User talk:Sca|talk]]) 16:42, 8 April 2010 (UTC) :PS: The German Wiki entry says: ''Es wurde nach Tallinn geschleppt und dort zum Zielschiff umgebaut'' — "It was towed to Tallinn and there converted into a target ship." [[User:Sca|Sca]] ([[User talk:Sca|talk]]) 16:48, 8 April 2010 (UTC) ::PPS: Compare to the postwar fate of [[German cruiser Prinz Eugen]]. [[User:Sca|Sca]] ([[User talk:Sca|talk]]) 16:58, 8 April 2010 (UTC) :::According to Erich Gröner, the ship was broken up in Tallinn. [[User:Parsecboy|Parsecboy]] ([[User talk:Parsecboy|talk]]) 16:20, 12 May 2010 (UTC) {{Talk:SMS Schleswig-Holstein/GA1}} == Clarification == It was apparently sunk in 1944 so that makes me wonder how it was scuttled in 1945, or maybe what is meant by scuttled. Was it somehow raised out of the water or was the water so shallow that it simply grounded the ship but not cause it to sink below the water surface. Was it used for anything in between these times if it had been salvageable in some way? — Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[Special:Contributions/71.226.196.247|71.226.196.247]] ([[User talk:71.226.196.247|talk]]) 23:49, 4 September 2013 (UTC) :No, the crew just wanted to make sure the wreck was as destroyed as possible. [[User:Parsecboy|Parsecboy]] ([[User talk:Parsecboy|talk]]) 15:55, 7 September 2013 (UTC) == January 2014 review == Reading the "World War 2" chapter I found some mistakes: # Westerplatte wasn't any "fortress" - this is tipical German interpretation. # The battle of Westerplatte ended on September 7, not 8; in my opinion huge mistake. # ''Gotenhaven'' - what should be explained - was Nazi's name of [[Gdynia]], Polish sea port turned into the safe [[Kriegsmarine]] base. # Schleswig Holstein was bombed by the allied aircraft at the [[Bay of Gdańsk]], that's why its crew could be send to nearby located [[Malbork|Marienburg]], and that's why the ship was taken after the war by Soviets. I believe it will help to improve this featured article. [[User:Belissarius|belissarius]] ([[User talk:Belissarius|talk]]) 02:15, 17 January 2014 (UTC) == Save for later == Ref for more details on the action at Westerplatte [https://books.google.com/books?id=lTW_dftTTUcC&pg=PA99&dq=battleship+schleswig-holstein+westerplatte&hl=en&sa=X&ei=MwnsUtyIFa78yAHF-YGwAQ&ved=0CCkQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=battleship%20schleswig-holstein%20westerplatte&f=false here]. [[User:Parsecboy|Parsecboy]] ([[User talk:Parsecboy|talk]]) 11:00, 18 September 2015 (UTC)
